Name: shilpa b
Title: A  walk through th depth of tribal pockets providing a peak into art',predominantly significant in human life,this art-gallery i
Review: A drive into th heartland of th city through th bustling streets and alleys...one lands into this place of Art amidst th Greens which aptly showcases Art, Culture and Tribal Gallery. Different categories of items are on display...any Art-lover will definitely enjoy th variety of exibits that have been extensively showcased. The aesthetic emotion in th atmosphere is what any Art lover would fall for. A simple place but with a livin' soul' of design and visual art.

Name: sinan ertay
Title: Hidden treasure for art lovers and artists
Review: It was my first week in Chennai. I was looking for interesting places to visit by trip advisor and similar applications. I read the reviews about Cholamandal Artists’ Village and I searched photos in order to have a better idea, Scores and reviews were good, but not so interesting. Firstly google map sent us to a rich man’s big farm. When we found the correct address of the village, there was nobody but only two responsibles (one of them can talk English), lovely dogs in the garden and a two layers medium size gallery with beatiful paintings. The wonderful surprise started when I asked the possibility to meet up with one of the artists who was living in the village. The artist Latha Gopal was the daughter of one of the artist founders (K.S. Gopal) of the village. We learned from her the wonderful story of the village. She gave detailed informations about the paintings and their pioneer painters, also her painting. She also showed us the queen of the trees in the garden: wonderful “Banyan Tree”. Some important informations about the village: you can buy very important paintings exposed in the gallery (not in the museum) starting with the prices of 2000 euros. Daily rent of the exposition gallery is around 40 euros (area is far from the city but the place is so meaningful). Free drawing workshops on Sundays 10h-14h. This village is one of the centers of Madras Movement: contemporary step in Indian painting and sculpture. Besides, Madras (Chennai) Fine Art School is öne of the oldest fine art institutes of İndia. Entrance is less than 1 euro/person. Thank you Latha that you showed us some part of the hidden treasure in Cholamandal.

Name: Radhika Narasimhan
Title: Silent Cholamandalam village
Review: It’s an offbeat spot yards away from Adyar. Filled with greenery International sculpture park welcomed us, followed by museum. Paying an entry fee we admired a great deal of paintings. From there we walked to Grand Oriole and then proceeded towards Japanese museum. An ideal spot for art lovers and sculptures. A unique spot to experience silence.

Name: Eileen108
Title: Great Support to Artists!
Review: Great place to view contemporary art by a number of talented individuals. Great that such a place exists! Definitely can recommend a pleasant visit to support the community.

Name: brigid f
Title: Cholamandal Artist's Village
Review: The art is amazing.  Well worth the uber ride. A bit difficult to find entry.  While it would be nice to have more information on the artists, if you like modern art do not miss this.  And you can buy pieces of the art or small items from the gift area. Lovely.

Name: Soumyajit Saha
Title: Cholamandal Artists Village
Review: Cholamandal Artists Village is a very good place to watch creativity. People here are very artistic and you will see many creations.

Name: divgic
Title: Unique Indian modern art collectoiin.
Review: I am not a modern art fan.  The art here, however, blew me away - it was so evocative of what I believe to be India that it made me aware of the socio-political contexts of art.  The museum itself is so unassuming that it's easy to pass it by.  But it's become a highlight of my Madras experience, and I will re-visit with friends (my friends from Spain were impressed too) whenever I can.

Name: Phil H
Title: Interesting selection of local art
Review: Brave the traffic and you arrive at a small but interesting art gallery with a permanent exhibition and a gallery with art works from some noted artists for sale.  There is an interesting sculpture display in the garden and an upstairs and downstairs gallery with paintings, drawings and sculpture.  Worth the visit.  No refreshments there.

Name: WorldcitizenCH
Title: Modern Art in Chennai
Review: Art addicted should come here, there is some beautiful art pieces! Staff is very nice. Never saw till visit such a modern Buddha ! Other art pieces are amazing ! There is also a nice retrospective from Vasudev. Very nice paintings and other works...

Name: Rathish Nair
Title: Very Interesting - For ART LOVERS
Review: Forewarning - The Artists village would be a very good attraction for the ART LOVERS only.  If you have no inclination for ART- better skipLocated off the main road and on the ECR Road, it is set up in a very peaceful environment. There is a small entrance fee to the main museum.  The artifacts and paintings are worth once a look. Lot of contemporary works in display. There are some books and souvenirs that one can buy too.

Name: UtpalShah
Title: Excellent vibe and beautiful art works
Review: After visiting the museum, don't forget to take a stroll into the artist residential / work area. You will find many artists working on their next masterpieces. I bought a nice painting, which they packed very nicely for flight travel. It arrived without a scratch.

Name: Eric G
Title: A Collective Exhibition of South Indian Modern Art
Review: On my way back to Chennai from Dakshin Chitra museum, I went here. I like modern art so I did enjoy my visit. Sample works by contemporary artists are exhibited here. Almost half of the exhibit is permanent (called "the museum"), and the other half is temporary and the works are on sale (called "the gallery"). Most or some of the artists live around the gallery, within the "art village" but it is not easy to visit them. It seems there are no "open door" days and hours when the public may visit their studios.

Name: YashiR25
Title: One time visit if on ECR
Review: For those who are too much into Arts. I just liked one painting there which was on first floor right side. Well-maintained, if happens to be on ECR, worth a one time visit.

Name: Atul G
Title: For those who enjoy modern art
Review: This artists’ village displays modern and abstract paintings and sculptures from India. I very much enjoyed perusing the works on displays and it is definitely worth seeing if you are interested in the art scene from India. The pieces are well-presented and there is plenty of information about the different artistic movements throughout the 20th century and some of their most prominent artists. Outside their is a small sculpture park that is less interesting as most of your time is better spent indoors. It isn’t a big complex at all and can easily be covered in around an hour if you see it comfortably. Definitely one to see for art enthusiasts.

Name: dinesh_j84
Title: Art Gallery with Decent Collection
Review: This Art Gallery is located close to the VGP Theme Park along the ECR. It displays paintings of various themes. The art gallery is well maintained. It is not usually crowded as it is away from the center of the city.

Name: Vilasitha V
Title: worst experience......nothing special to see over there...waste of time...I personally do not recommend anyone to go for
Review: nothing special to see over there...waste of time...I personally do not recommend anyone to go for this place

Name: Thusanee L
Title: A delightful sight for art lovers
Review: This museum with contemporary art is such a nice place to spend an afternoon with. I got so amused by their history. You will also have the chance to meet the artists during the morning. I strictly recommend to watch "Krishnaa" by A. Selvaraj. My absolute favourite! But i wish they had workshops for publics.

Name: Sunand S
Title: A very peaceful art gallery - A Must visit for Art lovers - A hidden gem in chennai
Review: For all those , who have interest in arts , some very beautiful art work . You can also purchase few paintings starting from 5000/- INR to 60,000/-INR  :) Not that big ,you can easily cover all in 1hrs to 2 hrs Ticket 30rs for adults and below 5 year kids are freeAbout Place-Cholamandal Artists' Village, established in 1966, is the largest artists' commune in India. Its artists are credited for the Madras Movement of Art (1950s–1980s), which brought modernism to art in South India. Their work is widely recognized as some of the best art produced in postwar India and is shown regularly in galleries across the country. Several Cholamandal artists have also shown in Europe, the United States and South America.In the village Injambakkam, 9 km from Chennai, India, it has over 20 resident painters and sculptors, who live as a community and pool their skills. They run the Artists Handicrafts Association, a cooperative which manages the village and sale of works through the permanent exhibition at the complex, which includes paintings, sketches, terra-cotta/stone/metal sculptures, batiks and handicrafts etc., making the village a self-supporting entity

Name: RAJKUMAR A
Title: Not for general public, Strictly!
Review: This place should not have been made a public attraction. Unless you have extreme interest towards art or you're an ardent artist, this place is a complete disaster. Don't waste your time and money by visiting this place. There's absolutely nothing here other than paintings and stones or statues.

Name: Krzysztof N
Title: Better than I expected
Review: It is a kind of open-air museum with many examples of Indian architecture and village houses. You can also see here how sari is made, pottery, etc. The best part for me was surprisingly short videos presented in few places. That way man can learn about ordinary life in Indian home, family hierarchy, duties, privileges, etc. The museum is not offensive regarding number of details and site layout - very friendly from that side.

Name: Dilip S
Title: Where I Learnt Lot
Review: The 10th December , 2016 is the date we will never forget . On this day we first visited Dakshin Chitra and then very fortunate to visit Cholamandal an Artists’ Village brainchild of K C S Paniker , eminent painter and visionary who dreamt of an art Indian in spirit and world wide contemporary .  The place we visited was not a village , it was a multum in parvo , telling the story of the strength and the weakness of present day Indian art .  Thirty painters and sculptures acquired 3.5 ha of land 8 km south of Adyar  on then muttukadu road in 1965 to start the Village in order to rehabilitate the creative artists . Here the artists paints or sculpts through the major part of the day and earns through the sale of his art . The Village is perhaps the first of its kind anywhere in the world . On 1st feb 2009 , the Cholamandal Centre for Contemporary Art consisting of the K C S Paniker Museum of the Madras Movement , two commercial A C gallaries , Labernum and Indigo , and an open air international sculptures park surrounding the complex was inaugurated . Here we could revisit Paniker . The notion of a three dimensional linear space that the Renaissance  painters advanced and which they applied in the rule of perspective , and the pure theory of it which the cubists abstracted later on are to date the only technically sound solutions to the issue between drawing and picture . Paniker was one who would not submit his subject to received theory in its applied or pure form . Rather than relent Paniker broke off and set out arguing his own case . He made his departure in the landscape , the genre he used extensively for developing his arguments . Instead of solidifying the free space with the straight line structure of perspective or with regular blocks of colour , he made it into a fluid thing held up with a distribution of highly accented , broken and curling lines . The irregular edges of colour that one gets as a bonus when working in water colour , a medium in which Paniker excelled , might have suggested to him this very unconventional abstraction .   The second artist we studied was the sculptor Nandgopal . His sculpture looked open and perhaps continues to , probably because it Is not closed on all sides like something in the round , also because it is not spatial , I e , something fixed compositionally  in space .  We highly appreciated A Selavraj’s painting , which absorbed the rhythmic freedom that makes the dancer’s body reflect the pure joy of movement . A Selavraj is a born dancer . The dancing experience evolved his style both in painting and sculpture . It acquired a fluidity  and in painting he gets a flow of light and  shadow .  His style remains purely figurative and he felt inspired by dancers , deities , musicians and village dames .There were many inspirational sculptures around the complex , some of which were Dream of the black sun by N D Rajsekharan , the zen inspired  Emptiness by Hiroshi Mikami , Figure  by Kanyai Kunhiraman , Head by Mall Walsh , Landscape by Theo tan Have , Lord M..  by S Kannappan  , Seed by Nagji Patel from my Vadodara ,  Shape by Olaf Mooij , Temple by Cune van Groeningrn and  View by Ajit Chakravarti  .  There was painting by Dich Donker too .

Name: RAM779
Title: Artwork
Review: All it is Displays of Small to Medium size art work in 2 buildings.. Could be a Artist's haven but for everybody's best interest..

Name: ArunaSrinivas
Title: For Artists and Art Lovers!
Review: It's located on the ECR. A quiet place where artists work and their artwork is displayed both for viewing and sale.

Name: Bharatbackpacker
Title: For serious art lovers
Review: The artist village maybe more relevant to Artists themselves rather than tourists. Even though an art lover myself, was very disappointed as the museum while show casing works of the artists of the Madras Art Movement lead by Panicker, there is very little on the movement itself. I suppose that the commune still exists is an achievement by itself. Entrance to museum is ticketed.

Name: Arrul
Title: To the people who love Art
Review: I visited this place a long back in 2010 , As an art lover I always look for something like this in the city and this village is exceptional, Art contributions display works of prominent artists including M. Senathipathi, Late A.P. Santhanaraj, P.S. Nandhan, S.G. Vasudev, K.V. Haridasan, Thotta Tharani, Sculptor S. Nandagopal.

Name: Ellen C
Title: worth a visit
Review: This artist commune offers contemporary artists a place to work and display their paintings, sculpture and craft. There is a permanent gallery as well as a sales gallery. It is interesting to see how some of the ancient art influences these very modern pieces. Lovely gardens, and a sculpture park surround an old banyan tree.

Name: GRVenky
Title: Beautiful paintings, good collection
Review: On the way to Mahabalipuram, one can visit this place for a lovely experience of going through a most beautiful collection of paintings and a few metal sculptures. Time worth spending  A few of the paintings take your breath away.

Name: Shyamis
Title: Artist commune
Review: This is an artist commune and it is a beautiful place to visit. The place has resident artists and sculptors.

Name: Manash_Baruah
Title: Signifiant collection of art
Review: The art gallery has great ambiance.  Located amidst a quite locality, the building has very good collection of art since 1950s.  A visit will refresh your minds with great work by the exponents of art

Name: madhu507
Title: Great art display
Review: Don't go with any expectations...very good paintings..Adult entry ticket 10 & for kids 5 rs....this is just my opinion

Name: kevinjohn1991
Title: Great Art Variety!!!
Review: One can find many interesting paintings here. There is not a lot one can learn from here as there no proper curators around. This place on the ECR road and one can drop in on the way to Mahabalipuram. The tickets are very cheap.*Visit*

Name: Remya
Title: Great variety of art
Review: Visited it on the way to mahabalipuram from chennai Adult entry tickets for 10/- INR and kids for 5/- INR There are books, paintings and creations from metal and stone.It is a result of the Madras Movement for liberating and inspiring the Indian artists esp during the Post Freedom Era.It is a refreshing and great way to see the mix of Indian mythological with western strokes. Time _For an hour max No photography insideOutside few creations are allowed to be clicked Free parking outside Calm and colourful experience Allowed to buy t-shirt, mugs, plates for 300 and 750 INR depending on the size.  Though most books are for reference there are few for purchase. Tip_ drop in on the way from chennai to mahabalipuram

Name: Jude G
Title: Expected more
Review: Truth to say, I expected more from this place given that it pioneered a new art movement in chennai. However, I found some paintings on sale and others for display only. There were books but no artist to interact with and not much information about the movement in the museum. There are beautiful sculptures and buildings in the area. But I did not learn much as the works were not curated properly. This is just my opinion.

Name: Vijay Raj Selvam
Title: Must visit for Architecture lovers
Review: This place will be really a treat for all those who love art and architecture. To be clear, its only place for art lovers.. Others please avoid. You will be really bored here!

Name: BananaLu
Title: 4 stars for the symbol of the place! For art lovers!
Review: People can actually not exactly visit the whole Cholamandal artists’ village because we are not supposed to enter the artists’ houses but there is an interesting gallery split on two floors with a permanent collection and few items that can be purchased, and another gallery that seems to contain only temporary exhibitions. Though small the collection is made of paintings (oil, acrylic, and water colour), sketches, drawings, and sculptures. Sadly only few art pieces have titles and none has explanations written on the side to enlighten the visitors on the artists’ messages.I would not advice to tourists who have a limited time to go there as the galleries are very small and do not contain items that will blow their mind, but I would definitely advice people who stay in Chennai to go there. It is indeed said to be the largest artists’ community of India and in any case it must one of the only such communities able to survive like this today. It is also an important part of India modern art history (village inaugurated in the 60s!) and art lovers should not miss it!The artists also propose free sketches classes on weekends! A good opportunity for children and even adults if you live in this area!

Name: barry p
Title: truly wonderful array of 1960-2015 artists
Review: laid out exceptionally well, many for sale. if serious buyer can visit many artists homes also.  for any art lover, a must visit

Name: Papayaved
Title: Nice museum of modern art
Review: It's not so big museum of modern art like in Delhi, but and price is cheap. Take a walk in village among villas of artists, you will find more interesting artworks.

Name: rea2der
Title: Artist Village
Review: Recently visited the artist village with friends.It is located in Injambakkam and it is one of the  largest artists' commune in India . This place serves as a  good connection of modern Indian arts. Entry ticket amount is rs 20 and cameras are strictly not allowed.The artists live in the same village.Books are available for sale and it is little costly.On the whole a good place to learn about Indian arts.

Name: SagarVS
Title: For art lovers
Review: Here many artists live in one community. Visitors can meet various artists including painters, sculptors etc. This place has churned out many eminent artists over the years. If you are into paintings (modern and traditional) and other forms, it would be worth your time to spend some time here. This is on the way to mahabalipuram so if you can see the artists village on the way without having to make an exclusive trip.

Name: Tribhuvan J
Title: Good collection of Modern Indian arts
Review: This place has good connection of modern Indian arts. Entry ticket is negligible. The artists live in the same colony. If you are interested you can go buy their arts.

Name: Chandrasekaran N
Title: Artistic village
Review: This village is on the East Coast Road of chennai on the way to Mamallapuram. Arts in all forms can be seen. It is an artistic place. Budding artists and sesoned artists frequently visit this place. Even if we are not artists we will love this place. A nice place to spend useful time learning about Indian arts.A visit to this artistic place is really worth the time and money spent.

Name: srk800
Title: Artistic vilage
Review: Great show casing of Art and crafts of Rich country like India at one place.Worth visiting by any one who comes to chennai

Name: wanderer2174
Title: Good for visiting once atleast.
Review: Its heaven for the art connosieurs and even for people not too much into arty stuff, its good to see this place once. There are various art forms displayed here and one can only stretch one's imagination. The trees in the campus are also very beautiful and there is a small shack/ restaurant where one get's lovely cold fruit juices freshly made. It was very hot for us in October so please wear light clothes and carry sunglasses.

Name: crazyrahul78
Title: i just love this village...
Review: go with some one who really knows about the art.. then u ll come to know the beauty of this village. The world here is so calm n beautifull.. I went here for twice n every time it give me fresh experiance.

Name: Mediaplanner01
Title: Very serene
Review: Everything about the place from the art to artists to the seashore nearby was becalming and soothing. A definite stopover en route to Mahabs. Some of the sculptures were out of the world....

Name: gmj_ni
Title: An artist's paradise
Review: If you are an artist or understand art in its many forms this is one place to visit.I visited the place because one of my lecturers lived in the vicinity just to kill a couple of hours. But I ended up spending the entire afternoon and evening there. Its a great place and parking wasn't a problem.

Name: Bhramanti-Pune
Title: Not much to see than an Art Gallary...
Review: This trip was avoidable.... Not much there to look. Dakshin Chiteq, a bit more commercial was much better.

Name: Gowthami R
Title: south indians modeling Houses
Review: People of Tamil nadu,karnataka,kerala,and andhrapradesh states cultures,and the mannerism,and their Living shown as real

Name: suraghavan
Title: Artist village
Review: All travelers who would like to see how artisans work, one should visit this place lots of things for youngsters and elders alike

Name: Sudeshna G
Title: Ok.Not my type of place
Review: Its ok  ,teaches you all  about the culture of south India.But too much money for entry fees.I would better spend it iin golden beach rather than learning and  understnding the  culture.

Name: Anindia
Title: Great place and nice cafe called Shiraz
Review: Foliage of trees all around interspersed with bungalows-A very nice and p[pleasant sight to be in this village on ECR road Chennai. Cafe Shiraz is the most brilliant thing inside- A MUST Visit. The owners Nazreen and her brother Darush are awesome hosts. Anything and everything she cooks is our favourites!!

Name: vickykksa
Title: Good if you're a connoisseur of the arts
Review: We made a short stop at the Artist's Village on the way back to Chennai. It was quite late, so we were the only visitors there. We met one of the artists who had some of her paintings exhibited;  that was quite exciting, to meet a real live artist.The paintings and sculptures were interesting, but were not all 'understandable' to non-conneoisseurs like us!The banyan tree in the garden was fascinating,though. Unfortunately the cafe was not open, so we didn't get a chance to sit and enjoy a cup of tea there.

Name: rprabhoo
Title: Packaged Heritage
Review: Run behind the materialistic world. Hectic schedules and lofty targets may stress you. When you look back, you realise that you forgot where from you started. Worse still your children dont even know WHAT is that 'where from'. Cool place to remind your heritage and treasures through arts and sculpture.

Name: Ronzown
Title: Shaping up finally
Review: Have been coming her since my childhood, but finally Chalamandalam - is becoming the happening art and artists hang-out it should've always been. Try to get yourself on the invitation list of their Friday art movies club and get your palate tickled at the lovely Iranian cuisine at the Shiraz cafe. And amble around making friends with the resident artists and pick up a conversation or a piece of art.

Name: Arvind V
Title: Excellent concept
Review: it was a great idea to let know this generation of the culture that existed in the immediate previous lifetime / generation on the way of life in their own motherland. exposure to lifestyle, food habits, clothing, designs to name a few - very apt and unique

Name: 491max
Title: Good variation of Art
Review: Nice to walk around to see new art inside the well capt building. It has a outside garden with statues from Artists who came from all over the world to make art.

Name: tripfreak54
Title: Artists Village
Review: Cholamandal Artists Village was established in 1960's and has a permanent exhibition of paintings, sketches, terracotta sculptures, batiks and other crafts.Located about 20 km's from Chennai.

Name: Been2Bagan
Title: Contemporary landmark
Review: Cholamandal Artist's village has a beautiful gallery dedicated to the great artists of the Madras Movement. An atmospheric setting with a huge banyan, an Iranian cafe, and gardens make the gallery a nice outing. On the East Coast Road on the way to Dakshinachitra and Mammallapuram, Cholamandal can easily be bundled with a visit to these sites.

Name: Geo47
Title: Great fun
Review: A good initiative. Lots of do and see and a great learning opportunity too. This would be a great place to take children.

Name: G.Visukumar
Title: Every Artist should visit
Review: This place has huge collection of paintings from very popular artists'. Upcoming artists can learn more from those paintings.

Name: Resident-Non-Indian
Title: Great food at the cafe
Review: Don't miss having Sunday brunch here.  On weekdays they serve mostly snacks, but the Sunday brunch is delicious Iranian food.

Name: Ram M
Title: South Indian Contemporary Art at its best
Review: The Madras Movement... Very interesting history and beautiful museum/ gallery. The village itself is amazing with its atmosphere. Ofcourse more interesting as an art spot than a tourist spot.Has a lovely Iranian run restaurant, Shiraz, as well and the Sunday brunch is amazing. Some very good artefacts on sale - quite moderately priced for art works. The ambiance is what attracts visitors.
